data.title: 2011* Lawrence County Record
data.meta_description: 2009 OBITUARIES - A Published: Friday, February 5, 2010 1:12 PM CST Obituaries published in the Lawrence County Record earlier this year. HARVEY DONAL
data.text:
2009 OBITUARIES J-K

Published: Friday, February 5, 2010 9:59 AM CST

Obituaries published in the Lawrence County Record earlier this year.

LOREN B. JACKSON

Loren B. Jackson, 89, Mt. Vernon, formerly of Grove, Okla., died Tuesday, Aug. 4, 2009, at the Missouri Veterans’ Home/Mt. Vernon.

He was born Nov. 25, 1919, in Grove to Homer and Lillian (Nelson) Jackson. He attended school through the 11th grade and then enlisted in the United States Marine Corps. He served from November 1940 until December 1945. Following the service, he made his career as a painter.

Following cremation, committal of ashes will be held at Hickory Grove Cemetery, Grove, Okla., at a later date. Buchanan Funeral Home, Monett, handled local arrangements.

WILLIAM DALE JACKSON

William Dale Jackson, 66, Crane, died Saturday. May 2, 2009, in St. Luke’s Hospital, Kansas City.

He was born March 7, 1943, in Stone County to Lloyd and Edith Howard Jackson.

He married Lillian Charlene Letts Jan. 18, 1964. She survives.

While living in the Kansas City area, he was a police officer for the city of Gladstone. He returned to Stone County in the late ‘60s and was employed as a truck driver for various local companies. He had been a driver for Prestressed Castings for 23 years. He was a member of Teamsters Local 245. He attended the Hurley Church of God.

He was preceded in death by his parents.

Additional survivors include his children, Andrea Jackson, Crane, Brian “Tony” Jackson and Cami “Boomer” Bishop, both of Marionville, and Danielle Jackson-Harris, Springfield; three sisters, June Matney, Jeannie Huffines, Crane, and Joyce Gold, Hereford, Ariz.; and seven grandchildren.

Services were Thursday, May 7, in the Hurley Church of God, Hurley, under direction of Westrip Funeral Home, Crane. Burial was in Wrights Cemetery, Union City.

Donations may be made to St. Jude’s Children’s Hospital or Operation Smile Train.

ROSS DAVID JAKEWAY

Ross David Jakeway, 92, Aurora, died Sunday, Aug. 23, 2009, in his home.

He was born Aug. 10, 1917, in Caney, Kan..

He was a retired post office janitor and a lifelong resident of the area.

He was a member of the Galena Masonic Lodge, the Aurora Grand Square Dancers and the Crane Christian Church. He was a United States Army veteran. He was preceded in death by his wife, Betty “Lorene,” and one daughter, Linda Eisenhour.

Survivors include one son, Michael David Jakeway, and one daughter, Lisa Mitchell, both of Aurora; four grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren.

Services were Wednesday, Aug. 26, in Manlove-Stumpff Chapel, Crane, with Howard Mountcastle and Bruce Belin officiating. Burial was in Crane Community Cemetery.

CLETUS ROMAN JANUSICK

Cletus Roman Janusick, 74, Mt. Vernon, passed away at 6 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 4, 2009, at the Lawrence County Manor. He was born June 20, 1935, in Granville, Ill., the son of Leo and Hedwig (Geng) Janusick. On March 22, 1976, he married Barbara Asp in Geneva, Ill. Together, they lived in Oglesby, Ill., prior to moving to Missouri in 1995. They lived on their farm in Jerico Springs until his failing health brought them to Mt. Vernon in 2006. Cletus was a cattle farmer his entire life and was also a meat cutter, retiring at the age of 62.

Those surviving him include his wife, Barbara of Mt. Vernon; two daughters, Carol K. Janusick of Decatur, Ill., and Cheryl Marshall and husband, Mick, of Beulah, N.D.; two brothers, Arnold Janusick of Princeton, Ill., and Norbert Janusick of Bridgman, Mich.; two sisters, Corinne Michael of Princeton, Ill., and Beverly LaPuh of Granville, Ill.; two grandchildren, Will Marshall and his wife, Brandy, of Gillette, Wyo., and Robin Marshall of Bismarck, N.D.; and two great-grandchildren, Lainie and Kinlie. His parents, son, Gregory, and his sister, Arminda Yonkus, preceded him in death.

A memorial service will be held at 11 a.m. Saturday, Nov. 7, at the Fossett-Mosher Funeral Home, Mt. Vernon. Memorial donations may be made to the Humane Society, in care of the funeral home.

Online condolences may be shared at www.fossettmosherfuneralhome.com.

(Paid obituary)

JAMES L. JAYCOX

James L. Jaycox, 88, Bolivar, died Thursday, March 19, 2009, at Citizens Memorial Healthcare Facility, Bolivar.

He was born Nov. 21, 1920, on a farm near Crofton, Neb. He married Arlene Kube in 1942. She survives.

They moved to Bolivar in 1992. He was a member of Sacred Heart Catholic Church.

Additional survivors include four daughters, Janice Holland, Anamosa, Iowa, Judy Jaycox, Brighton, Joyce Freeman, Marionville, and Jeanette Ayers, Fort Plain, N.Y.; one sister, Elaine Morphew, Lake Park, Iowa; three brothers, Marion Jaycox, Sanborn, Iowa, Raymond Jaycox, Lake Park, and Leroy Tinkco, Sierra Vista, Ariz.; eight grandchildren; and seven great-grandchildren.

He was preceded in death by one son, James M.; three sisters, Lavonne Wells, Alice Mayden and Margaret Brash; and three brothers, Rex, Donald and Ralph Jaycox.

Mass of Christian burial was Monday, March 23, in Sacred Heart Catholic Church, Bolivar, with Father Pat Wissman officiating. Burial was in St. Wenceslaus Cemetery, Bolivar, under direction of Murray Funeral Home, Bolivar.

DANALEE ‘DEE’ JENKINS

DanaLee “Dee” Jenkins, 63, Cassville, died Monday, Sept. 14, 2009, in St. John’s, Springfield.

She was born May 2, 1946, in Wickenburg, Ariz., to Bill and Gladys (Akin) Gray. She married Harold L. Jenkins March 6, 1987, in Miami, Okla. He survives.

Additional survivors include one son, Monte Caldwell, Hoxie, Ark.; two daughters, Terri Meyers, Stratford, Okla., and Christi Rogers, Clever; two stepdaughters, Becky Jones, Aurora, and Patti Tucker, Marionville; 14 grandchildren; and 12 great-grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her parents.

She grew up and received her education in Oklahoma. She attended East Central University in Ada, Okla. She was a homemaker and a Christian.

No services are scheduled at this time. Arrangements are under direction of Fohn Funeral Home, Cassville.

ETHEL ‘ERNESTINE’ JENKINS

Ethel “Ernestine” Jenkins, 90, Mt. Vernon, died at 3:50 a.m. Saturday, Sept. 19, 2009, in the Lawrence County Manor, Mt. Vernon.

She was born April 20, 1919, in Miller to Ernest Jefferson and Lovie Jane (Abraham) Hunter. She was a 1938 graduate of Miller High School, worked for the Missouri Rehabilitation Center, U.S. Envelope and the Mt. Vernon MFA grocery store, in the meat department. She was a member of Onward Methodist Church.

Survivors include three daughters, Connie Brown, Everton, Jane Gossett, Ash Grove, and Patty Cornell, Wentworth; two sisters, Edna Beach, Greenfield, and Helen Faucett, Mt. Vernon; one brother, Carl Hunter, Coppell, Texas; four stepchildren, Donna Harris, Billie Wallace, Gene Jenkins and Joyce Forsyth; five grandchildren; 11 great-grandchildren; 12 great-great-grandchildren; seven step-grandchildren; and one step-great-grandchild.

She was preceded in death by eight brothers and sisters.

Graveside services were Monday, Sept. 21, in Miller Memorial Gardens Cemetery, under direction of Fossett-Mosher Funeral Home, Mt. Vernon.

Memorial donations may be made to Onward Methodist Church, in care of the funeral home.

RICHARD JENKINS

Richard Jenkins, 57, Verona, died Wednesday, Sept. 16, 2009, in Mt. Vernon.

He was born Dec. 26, 1951, in Aurora to Wilburn and Joan Williams Jenkins.

Survivors include his wife, Marjorie; five brothers, Darrell Jenkins, Humansville, and Gary Jenkins, Bob Jenkins, Tom Jenkins and Jerry Jenkins, all of Aurora; five sisters, Barbara McGlothlin, Blue Eye, Beverly Winsia, Springfield, Brenda Wrinkle, Reeds Spring, and Bebbie Robinson and Karen Koehler, both of Aurora; and one stepdaughter, Becky Daniels, Concordia.

He was preceded in death by his parents.

Graveside services were Tuesday, Sept. 22, in Maple Park Cemetery, Aurora, under direction of Peterson Funeral Chapel, Aurora.

RUFINA CHAPMAN (McCULLAH) JENKINS

Rufina Chapman McCullah Jenkins, 90, Springfield, died at 9 a.m. Saturday, Dec. 27, 2008.

She was born Sept. 11, 1918, in Browns Spring to Mason and Grace Chapman.

She married Ed Jenkins in Billings. He died May 28, 1994.

They moved to a farm near Verona in 1944.

They started a diesel engine shop in Springfield in 1956, which eventually became Jenkins Diesel Power.

She was also preceded in death by two brothers, Mason and Mac Chapman.

Survivors include three sons, Dan, Jim and Joe Jenkins; two grandsons; and four great-grandchildren.

Graveside services were Wednesday, Dec. 31, in Marionville IOOF Cemetery, under direction of Gorman-Scharpf Brentwood Chapel, Springfield.

In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Child Evangelism, P.O. Box 348, Warrensburg, MO 63383.

MARY ANN JIRIK

Mary Ann Jirik, 75, Springfield, died Wednesday, March 11, 2009, in her home following a long illness.

She was born March 24, 1933, in Verona to Albert and Flora Pfitzner Schmidt.

She lived in the Verona and Monett area until moving to Springfield in 1996. She married LeRoy Jirik on January 30, 1954. He survives.

Survivors include three daughters, Carolyn Oddo, Exeter, N.H., Marilyn Fare, Willard, and Donna Jirik, Springfield; one sister, Marguerite Butterworth, Monett; four brothers, Andrew Schmidt of Ark., Carl Schmidt, Rogersville, Leo Schmidt, and Ralph Schmidt, Monett, Mo.; and one grandson.

She was preceded in death by one brother, Joe Schmidt.

Funeral Mass was held on Monday, March 16, in St. Agnes Cathedral, Springfield, with the Rev. Michael McDevitt celebrant. Burial was in Resurrection Cemetery in Springfield.

DARRELL DEE JOHNSON

Darrell Dee Johnson, 52, Phoenix, Ariz., formerly of Mt. Vernon, died Tuesday, March 10, 2009, in his home.

He was born June 15, 1956, to Vester and Alice (Westerhold) Johnson. He graduated from Marionville High School in 1974 and from Cox College of Nursing in 1994. He worked as a hospice nurse.

Survivors include his wife, Kathy; two daughters, Jennifer Wallace, Aurora, and Kelly Ridderhoff, Mt. Vernon; their mother, Nancy (Stirewalt) Gould; two stepchildren, Natalie and Anthony; and six grandchildren.

Services were Friday, March 13, in Phoenix. His cremains will be buried at Pritchett Cemetery, near Chesapeake, at a later date.

DIA JOHNSON

Dia Johnson, 42, Mt. Vernon, formerly of Carthage, died at 8 a.m. Friday, July 17, 2009, at her home.

She was born Dec. 28, 1966, to John and Sharon (Webb) Stevens in Carthage.

She had lived in Mt. Vernon for the last several years. She graduated from Carthage High School in 1985 and from Missouri State University in December 1989, with a bachelor’s degree in social work. She was a member of Beta Sigma Phi and was employed as a social worker for Seasons Hospice in Springfield.

She married Robert Johnson Nov. 12, 1994, in Carthage. He survives.

Additional survivors include one son, Jon Nolan Johnson, of the home; her parents, John and Sharon Stevens, Carthage; and one sister, Lisa Stevens-Davis, Willard.

Services were Tuesday, July 21, at the Ulmer Funeral Home Chapel, Carthage. Burial was in Park Cemetery, Carthage.

Memorial contributions may be made to the Susan B. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, in care of the funeral home.

EFFIE IRENE JOHNSON

Effie Irene Johnson, 95, Arkansas City, Kan., died Thursday, Jan. 29, 2009, at the Medical Lodge East Nursing Home, Arkansas City.

She was born Jan. 6, 1913, in Viola to Arthur and Annie (Collins) Allen.

She moved to Arkansas City in 1934 and moved to Missouri in 1966. She helped her father on the farm and later owned her own farm in Purdy. In 1972, she returned to Arkansas City, where she owned and operated several restaurants. She was a Christian.

She married Don Johnson Aug. 20, 1950, in Arkansas City. He died Dec. 26, 1967.

Survivors include one son, Martin King, Arkansas City; one sister, Lois Buckley; three brothers, George, Emmett and Kenneth Allen; four grandchildren; 14 great-grandchildren; and three great-great-grandchildren.

She was also preceded in death by one son, Lee Roy King, two sisters, three brothers and one grandson.

Graveside services were Tuesday, Feb. 3, in McGuire Cemetery, Viola, under direction of Crafton-Cantrell Funeral Home, Aurora.

HAILEY RICHELLE JOHNSON

Hailey Richelle Johnson, 11 years old, of Joplin, passed away Thursday, Sept. 3, 2009, at home.

Hailey was born Nov. 16, 1997, to Andy and Angie Johnson of Joplin. She attended the sixth grade at South Middle School and enjoyed riding horses. She had Cerebral Palsy and was unable to verbally communicate, but she lit up the room with her smile and contagious laugh. She will be deeply missed by all those who knew her.

Additional survivors include her siblings, Miranda, Dillon and Devon Johnson of the home; grandparents, Eddie and Allene Roach of Joplin, Johnnie and Rexine Johnson of Granby; great-grandmother, Jewell Roach of Mt. Vernon; uncles, Brian and Tracy Roach of Mt. Vernon, Ted and Billie Johnson of Webb City; cousins, Kirsten, Zacharie and Mackenzie Roach of Mt. Vernon, and Chandler Johnson of Webb City.

Services were held at 10 a.m. Tuesday, Sept. 8, 2009, at Greenwood Baptist Church, Joplin. Visitation was 6 to 8 p.m. Monday at Parker Mortuary Chapel, Joplin.

Donations may be made to Horses for Hope Riding Center in Baxter Springs, Kan. You may view the obituary and a video at parkermortuary.com.

(Paid obituary)

HERBERT M. JOHNSON

Herbert M. Johnson, age 89, of Mt. Vernon, passed away at 6:12 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 1, 2009, at St. John’s Hospital in Springfield. He was born July 26, 1920, in Paris Springs, the son of William O. and Almeda (Meismer) Johnson.

Herbert served his country in the United States Army during World War II, and he worked for Carnation Canning Company in Mt. Vernon for 30 years. He was a member of the American Legion Post 137 of Mt. Vernon, a member of Teamsters Union and a member of the First Presbyterian Church in Mt. Vernon. On Oct. 4, 1941, he married Freda Blanch Hill of Marionville.

Those surviving him include his wife of 68 years, Freda, Mt. Vernon; one daughter, Sharon Schnake and her husband, Leeroy, of Ludlow; one son, Gary Johnson and his wife, Helen, of Lees Summit; four grandchildren, Carrie Gilliland, Shari Wells, Stuart Johnson and Rebekkah Stuteville; seven great-grandchildren; three great-great-grandchildren; and several nieces and nephews. His parents and eight brothers and sisters preceded him in death.

Funeral services were Monday, Oct. 5, in the Fossett-Mosher Funeral Home, Mt. Vernon. Burial, with military honors, was in the Mt. Vernon City Cemetery.

On line condolences may be shared at www.fossettmosherfuneralhome.com.

(Paid obituary)

SANDRA LEE JOHNSON

Sandra Lee Johnson, 42, Miller, died in her home at 4:25 p.m. Friday, Jan. 9, 2009.

She was born July 21, 1966, in Jefferson City to Richard L. and Geraldine (Hall) Baker.

She was a 1984 graduate of Miller High School, a cook for Miller High School and was of the Christian faith.

Survivors include three sons, Gary Wayne Stockton and Casey Lee Stockton, both of Miller, and Corey Lee Stockton, Republic; one brother, Rick Baker, Norco, Calif.; and one grandson.

She was preceded in death by her parents.

Services will be at 10 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 17, in Morris-Leiman-Mosher Funeral Home, Miller.

In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the family to assist with funeral expenses, in care of the funeral home.

WILLIS JOHNSON

Willis Johnson, 93, Ash Grove, died Sunday evening, March 22, 2009, in University Hospital, Columbia, following a short illness.

He was born in Halltown and was a lifelong resident of the Halltown and Ash Grove areas, until moving to Columbia to be near his son and family.

He was a farmer and stockman and was a member of the Paris Springs United Methodist Church. He was a judge (commissioner) for the Eastern District of Lawrence County for 10 years. He married Helen J. Johnson March 23, 1940. She died March 16, 2007.

He was also preceded in death by four brothers, Edwin, Olan, Wesley and Billie Johnson, and one sister, Gwen Fine.

Survivors include a son, Lyle Johnson, Columbia; a brother, Calvin Johnson, Everton; a sister, Retha Ella Berry, Overland Park, Kan.; two grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren.

Services were Thursday, March 26, in Wilson-Brim-Daniel Chapel, Ash Grove, with Dr. Larry Fine officiating. Burial will be in Misemer Cemetery, west of Halltown.

CLYDE EARL JONES

Clyde Earl Jones, 92, Ashland, Neb., died Friday, May 15, 2009, at his home in Ashland.

He was born Feb. 19, 1917, in rural South Bend, Neb., to William A. and Etta (Miller) Jones.

He attended a rural school near South Bend through the eighth grade.

He married Ruth L. Holiday Nov. 5, 1941, in Wahoo, Neb. She survives.

He entered the United States Navy Nov. 19, 1942, and served during World War II on several naval supply ships in the Atlantic. He was honorably discharged Oct. 9, 1945, as a Seaman First Class, V6 USNR.

After the war, he returned to farm in the South Bend area for nine years. In 1955, he and Ruth moved to their home in Ashland, where he worked for the rock quarry, operating the crusher. He was also employed for the State of Nebraska at the Greenwood Interchange Scale as an officer and worked at Campbell’s Farm Supply Store in Ashland.

He and Ruth retired in 1978, and moved to Florida for 12 years. They moved to Mt. Vernon to be close to family, where they stayed for 18 years. They recently moved back to the Ashland area.

He was preceded in death by four brothers, Clinton, John, Lester and Lloyd; and six sisters, Mildred, Hazel, Blanche, Mary, Pearl and Doris.

Services were Tuesday, May 19, at the United Methodist Church, Ashland, with Pastor John Ewton officiating. Burial, with military rites, was in Ashland Cemetery, Ashland, under direction of Marcy Mortuary, Ashland.

FRANCES EVELYN JONES

Frances Evelyn Jones, 88, Aurora, died Sunday, Aug. 9, 2009, in the Aurora Nursing Center.

She was born July 21, 1921, in Aurora to John and Mabel (Reynolds) Cline. She was a lifelong area resident.

Before retiring, she had worked for the Aurora School System as a cook. She was a member of the Elm Branch Christian Church.

She was preceded in death by her husband, Asa Monroe Jones, and one sister, Lois Basinger.

Survivors include one daughter, Carol Holmes, Crane; three grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren.

Services were Tuesday, Aug. 11, in Manlove-Stumpff Chapel, Crane, with Jerry Jenkins officiating. Burial was in Maple Park Cemetery, Aurora.

In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

MINFORD BRYAN JONES

Minford Bryan Jones, 80, Aurora, died at 10:15 p.m. Wednesday, May 20, 2009, at the Aurora Nursing Center.

He was born April 30, 1929, in Aurora to Bryan and Francis (Smith) Jones. He was a 1947 graduate of Aurora High School, a member of Orange Cumberland Presbyterian Church and a United States Army veteran. He worked as a printing press operator for MWM Dexter Printing Company for 41 years, retiring in 1991.

He married Avanell Bellis Aug. 22, 1951, in Eureka Springs, Ark. She survives.

Additional survivors include one son, Rick Jones, Monett; one daughter, Renee Rogers, Republic; and four grandchildren.

He was preceded in death by one sister, Marylee Elsey.

Services were Saturday, May 23, in Crafton-Cantrell Funeral Home, Aurora. Burial was in Orange Cemetery, north of Aurora.

Memorial donations may be made to Orange Cumberland Presbyterian Church, in care of the funeral home.

PAUL ‘JONESY’ JONES

Paul “Jonesy” Jones, 49, Fordland, died Sunday, July 5, 2009, in his home.

He was born Aug. 13, 1959, in Springfield to Leonard and Helen “Mincks” Jones.

He was a1977 graduate of Glendale High School. He had worked for the Frisco Railroad, John Deere and was a longtime area farmer and equipment dealer.

He married Janice (Hoffman) Kissinger Sept. 20, 2007. She survives.

Additional survivors include four stepsons, Beau Kissinger, Boston Kissinger and Van Tavenner, all of Fordland, and Jay Dee Tavenner, Rogersville; one brother, Darrell Jones, Halltown; and five grandchildren.

Services were Thursday, July 9, in Immanuel Lutheran Church, Springfield. Burial was in Galloway Cemetery, Springfield, under direction of Preston-Marsh Funeral Home, Rogersville.

Memorial donations may be made to the Immanuel Lutheran Church.

WILLIAM ‘BILL’ JONES

William “Bill” Jones, 81, Marionville, died at 3:50 a.m. Wednesday, Dec. 16, 2009, at the Ozarks Methodist Manor.

He was born Jan. 10, 1928, in Springfield to William Arthur and Mary Laverta (Arnhart) Jones.

Hew as a 1945 graduate of Marionville High School and was a United States Army veteran. He retired as a computer programmer for the Department of the Army in St. Louis.

Survivors include one sister, Wilda “Rosemary” Kenworthy, Portland, Ore. He was preceded in death by three brothers, Raymond, Earl and Jim Jones; and one sister, Laverta Mae Jones.

Arrangements are under direction of Crafton-Cantrell Funeral Home, Aurora. No services are planned.

DR. NORMAN E. JUSTUS

Dr. Norman E. Justus, 83, of Mt. Vernon, passed away at 3:05 p.m. Friday, June 26, 2009, in Cox Monett.

Dr. Justus was born Jan. 1, 1926, near Marionville to Frank and Anna (Rowe) Justus. He graduated from Verona High School in 1943; he retired as captain from the United States Navy, serving during World War II and the Korean Conflict. He graduated from the University of Arkansas in 1954 and Oklahoma State University in 1958.

Dr. Justus was a research agronomist with the United States Department of Agriculture for seven years and then served as superintendent of the University of Missouri Southwest Research Center for 23 years. He taught Sunday school in the First Baptist Church of Mt. Vernon, where he was a member for more than 40 years.

He married Annabelle Crouch on Sept. 7, 1946, and she preceded him in death on Sept. 16, 2006. His parents and a brother, John Robert Justus, also preceded him in death.

Survivors include two sons and their spouses, Jackie and Rosemary Justus of Bath, Pa., and Joel and Dana Justus, Aurora; one sister, Rosemary Arnold and her husband, Thomas, of Joplin; two brothers, Robert Justus and his wife, Mary, and Jerald Justus, all of Verona; six grandchildren, Jeremy Justus of Indianapolis, Ind., Julie Justus of Arlington, Va., Jennifer Doubleday and husband, Sonny, of Mt. Vernon, Jake Justus of Springfield, Joshua Justus and wife, Stephanie, of Verona, and Jared Justus of Aurora; and three great-grandchildren, Dallas and Dalton Doubleday of Mt. Vernon, and Iris Justus of Indianapolis.

Services were Tuesday, June 30, in the Fossett-Mosher Funeral Home, Mt. Vernon, with the Rev. Tim Burgess officiating. Burial, with full military honors, was in Mt. Vernon IOOF Cemetery.

In lieu of flowers, memorial may be made to the First Baptist Church Endowment Fund or the Missouri Baptist Children’s Home, in care of the funeral home.

Online condolences may be shared at www.fossettmosherfuneralhome.com.

(Paid obituary)

LOIS KAISER

Lois Kaiser, 75, Pierce City, died Sunday, Feb. 15, 2009, in her home.

She was born Feb. 13, 1934, in Freistatt to Gerhardt and Hilda Osterloh Schoen.

She retired in 1998 from Schreiber Foods in Monett. She was secretary for Liberty Neighborhood Watch, and a member of Lutheran Braille and Lutheran Women’s League at St. John’s Lutheran Church.

She married Paul Kaiser Jan. 3, 1954, in Freistatt. He survives.

Additional survivors include two sons, Mark Kaiser, Monett, and Michael Kaiser, Pierce City; one daughter, Vickie Elmore, Nixa; five grandchildren; and one great-grandchild.

She was preceded in death by one brother, Kenneth Schoen, and one sister, Lou Grehling.

Services were Thursday, Feb. 19, at St. John’s Lutheran Church, Monett, with the Rev. Richard Cody officiating. Burial was in St. John’s-McCormick Lutheran Cemetery, under direction of Buchanan Funeral Home, Monett.

Memorials may be made to the church or Community Hospice.

ETHEL PAULINE ‘POLLY’ KEE

Ethel Pauline “Polly” Kee, 75, Monett, died at 10:50 p.m. Tuesday, July 7, 2009, at Cox South, Springfield.

She was born in Oregon, Mo., Dec. 3, 1933, to Judge Curtis Paul and Ethel Charlene (Markt) Raiser. She married Norman Dean Kee April 18, 1954, at the First Presbyterian Church in Oregon. He survives.

They lived on the family farm at Forbes. After their sons graduated from high school, they moved to Bartlesville, Okla. After 10 years, they purchased a cattle farm at Monett.

She was employed at the Pettijohn & Eiser Law Firm in Oregon from 1953 to 1973. While in Oklahoma, she was employed at Phillips Petroleum Company in the office of the vice president of Phillips Research and Development from 1978 to 1988. After moving to Monett, she managed a flea market and was employed by the City of Monett in the recreation department until retirement in 2003.

She was a member of the First Presbyterian Church at Oregon. She was an elder and deaconess, served as superintendent of children’s church and taught Sunday school and Bible school.

She was active in 4-H clubs, extension clubs, Veterans of Foreign Wars Auxiliary, Missouri Federated Women’s Clubs, Business and Professional Women’s Club and Jane Phillips Sorority.

Additional survivors include two sons, Terry Dean Kee, Purdy, and Barry Curtis Kee, Aurora; three grandchildren; and two great-great-grandchildren.

Services were Saturday, July 11, at the First Presbyterian Church in Oregon, with the Rev. Walt Hamer officiating. Burial was in Maple Grove Cemetery, Oregon, under direction of Buchanan Funeral Home, Monett.

PHILLIP L. KELLEY

Phillip L. Kelley, 88, Joplin, died Tuesday, June 16, 2009, at the Missouri Veterans’ Home/Mt. Vernon.

He was born July 17, 1920, in Diamond to Roy B. and Reina A. (Beyer) Kelley.

He attended Diamond schools. He was called into the service Dec. 4, 1942. He served as a master sergeant in the United States Army Signal Corps, serving in New Guinea, the Philippine Islands and Luzon. He earned three overseas bars and a victory ribbon. He started a used car business in Diamond, which he operated until his retirement, at which time he moved to Joplin. When his health began to fail, he moved to the Missouri Veterans’ Home/Mt. Vernon.

He was a member of the Diamond Christian Church and the Diamond American Legion.

He married Imogene Kissel April 13, 1952, in Bentonville, Ark. She survives.

Additional survivors include one sister, Ruth M. Antle, Joplin.

He was preceded in death by one sister, Thelma Totzauer; and two brothers, Martin D. Kelley and Wilson W. Kelley.

Graveside services, with military honors, were Friday, June 19, at Diamond Cemetery, with Pastor James Lee officiating, under direction of Clark Funeral Home, Neosho.

In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Missouri Veterans’ Home/Mt. Vernon, in care of Clark Funeral Home, P.O. Box 66, Neosho, MO 64850.

AGNES MAE KENNEDY

Agnes Mae Kennedy, 94, Seneca, died at 10:57 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 12, 2009, at St. John’s, Joplin.

She was born June 26, 1915, in Buffalo, Okla., to Marcus Printice and Reta Mae Tabor Stansbury. She worked as an aide for St. John’s Hospital, and as a clerk for Newberry’s Dime Store, J.C. Penney and Checkerberry Square, retiring in 1987. She was of the Baptist faith.

She married Charles H. Kennedy Jan. 12, 1935. He died July 18, 2004.

Survivors include two sons, Chuck Kennedy, Seneca, and Don Kennedy, Marionville; two daughters, Judy L. David, Seneca, and Nan L. White, Salt Lake City, Utah; one brother, Leroy “Bud” Stansbury, state of Florida; seven grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren.

Graveside services were Thursday, Sept. 17, at Osborne Memorial Cemetery, with the Rev. Bob Simon officiating, under direction of Parker Mortuary, Joplin.

Memorial contributions may be made to the donor’s favorite charity.

NORMA JUNE KENYON

Norma June Kenyon, 83, Aurora, died at 10:30 a.m. Saturday, Oct. 17, 2009, at the Neighborhood of Quail Creek Nursing Home, Springfield.

She was born July 5, 1926, in Barry County to Howard and Burnice (Leamaster) Robbins.

She grew up in the White Oak community and remained in the Aurora area her entire life, excluding her stay at the Waterford at Iron Bridge and Quail Creek care centers in Springfield.

She married Bill “Bud” Kenyon March 3, 1946, in Aurora. He preceded her in death.

She was a member of the United Methodist Church, Aurora.

Survivors include one son, Dwain Kenyon, Camdenton; two daughters, Judy McCormack Springfield, and Jane Peebles, Nixa; two brothers, Bill Robbins, Springfield, and Charles Robbins, Oldfield; one sister, Sallie Roam, O’Fallon; five grandchildren; two step-grandchildren; seven great-grandchildren; eight step-great-grandchildren; and three step-great-great-grandchildren.

She was also preceded in death by one brother, Raymond Robbins.

Services were Thursday, Oct. 22, at the Crafton-Cantrell Funeral Home, Aurora. Burial will be in Maple Park Cemetery, Aurora.

REGINA SUSAN (MILLER) KERWOOD

Regina Susan (Miller) Kerwood, 58, Lamar, died Tuesday, Feb. 10, 2009, in St. John’s, Springfield.

She was born Aug. 17, 1950, in Jasper County to Fred and Jacqueline (Huffman) Miller. She worked as a children’s service worker investigating child abuse and neglect.

Her parents preceded her in death.

Survivors include one son, Korey Kerwood, Joplin; and two sisters, Robyn Wormington, Mt. Vernon, and Renee Wilson, Aurora.

Services were Saturday, Feb. 14, in Greenfield Funeral Chapel, with the Rev. Lee Miller officiating. Burial was in Pleasant Grove Cemetery.

Memorial contributions may be made to Pleasant Grove Cemetery.

HELEN KESTIN

Helen Kestin, 85, Aurora, died Monday, May 18, 2009, in her home.

Services were Thursday, May 21, in Peterson Funeral Chapel, Aurora. Burial was in Viola Cemetery.

AARON KIDD

Aaron Kidd, 50, Verona, died Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2009, at his home.

He was born Sept. 26, 1959, in Charlotte County, Fla., to Aaron Crocket and Gertie Mae (Tynes) Kidd. He worked as a welder for Tom’s Machine Shop and was a member of the Verona Volunteer Fire Department.

Survivors include three children, Billy, Anthony and Stacy; one stepdaughter, Stephanie Crabb and one stepson, Josh Mace, both of Aurora; two sisters, Patricia and Chris; and eight grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his parents.

Visitation was Sunday, Oct. 25, at Crafton-Cantrell Funeral Home, Aurora. No formal services were planned.

Memorial donations may be made to the family, in care of the funeral home.

FRED L. KIMBERLING

Fred L. Kimberling, 51, Billings, died Thursday, Aug. 6, 2009, at his home south of Clever.

He was born Dec. 1, 1957, in Aurora to Noble and Helen (Keener) Kimberling. He married Nancy Stubblefield. She died Aug. 22, 2005.

He was a supervisor with Hartman and Company, Springfield.

He was also preceded in death by three brothers, Dennis, Terry and Gary.

Survivors include one son, Greg Kimberling of the home; one stepson, Adam Fletcher, Aurora; his mother, Helen Cravens, Clever; and one brother, Larry Kimberling, Clever.

Services were Wednesday, Aug. 12, at Meadors Funeral Home, Clever. Burial was in Wright Cemetery, south of Clever.

Memorials may be made to an educational fund for Greg at Commerce Bank in Republic.

HOWARD LILBURN KING

Howard Lilburn King, 82, Springfield, died Tuesday, Dec. 1, 2009, in St. John’s, Springfield. He was a resident of the Missouri Veterans’ Home/Mt. Vernon.

He was born Jan. 30, 1927, in Caruthersville to Reuben J. and Laura Green King.

He served in the United States Navy during World War II as seaman second class radioman. He was assigned to the USS Iowa BB61 and received the Victory Medal, American Theatre Medal and the Asiatic Pacific Medal.

He graduated from Mississippi State University, Starkville, Miss., where he earned a bachelor’s degree in agriculture science.

He married Theda (Judy) Vaughn Nov. 18, 1951, in Caruthersville. She survives.

He was a civil service investigator for the federal government, working at stations in Kansas City, Jackson, Miss., and Washington, D.C. He retired in 1982 and moved to Springfield.

Additional survivors include two daughters, Patti Lambert and Theda Vaughn, both of Springfield; one son, Ed Vaughn, Springfield; four grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren.

Services, with full military honors, were Monday, Dec. 7, in the pavilion at the Missouri Veterans’ Cemetery, Springfield, under direction of Gorman-Scharpf Funeral Home, Springfield.

In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the charity of donor’s choice.

EDWARD ERNST EMIL KNAUST

Edward Ernst Emil Knaust, 83, Freistatt, died Monday, July 20, 2009, at Missouri Veterans’ Home/Mt. Vernon.

He was born June 10 1926, in Hoberg to Herman and Erna Ceddonia Pietsch Knaust.

He married Emma Resler Sept. 14, 1958, in Freistatt. She preceded him in death.

He was an auctioneer for 47 years. He graduated from Reisch Auction School in August 1942. He enjoyed farming, visiting with family and friends, Cardinal baseball games, attending high school sporting events and fishing. He was a lifelong member of Trinity Lutheran Church in Freistatt, where he was an elder, on the finance board and usher’s staff. He was a World War II veteran, where he spent 17 months stateside with 14 of those as an MP for 703rd Battalion. Since October 1946, he was a member of the Hubert H. Kleiboeker American Legion Post 419, serving as commander, vice commander, finance officer, sergeant at arms and chaplain.

Survivors include one son, Kenneth Edward Knaust, Monett; one daughter, Imogene Marie Knaust, Pierce City; two brothers, Elfred Knaust and wife Janet, and William Knaust and wife Ruth, all of Joplin; one sister, Rose Marie Knaust, Mt. Vernon; and many other relatives and friends.

He was preceded in death by one daughter, Ernadene Ruth Knaust, at birth; one brother, Raymond Knaust and his wife, Emma; and one sister, Flora Spree and her husband, Theodore.

Services were Friday, July 24, at Trinity Lutheran Church, Freistatt, with Pastor Ryan Buchmueller and Wilbur Claude officiating. Burial will be in the church cemetery, under direction of Buchanan Funeral Home, Monett.

(Paid obituary)

NANA KRAMER

Nana Kramer, 84, Purdy, died at 7:25 p.m. Friday, March 6, 2009, at Lawrence County Manor, Mt. Vernon, following a long illness.

She was born June 7, 1924, to Marguerite Marie and Joseph Nell George. She was a licensed practical nurse, retiring in 1990 after 47 years of service. She was a member of United Methodist Church in Raceland, Ky., and the Eastern Star.

She was married to Wayne Melvin Kramer. He preceded her in death.

She was also preceded in death by one daughter, Jenka Kramer.

Survivors include one son, Robert Holloway, South Point, Ohio; two daughters, Janina Dickerson, El Paso, Texas, and Nancy Grissom, Purdy; five grandchildren; and one great-grandchild.

Services were Friday, March 13, at Steen Funeral Home-Central Avenue Chapel, Ashland, Ky. Burial was in Sexton Cemetery, Danleyton, Ky.

ADA RUTH KROPF

Ada Ruth Kropf, 71, Halfway, died Friday, Nov. 27, 2009, at her home after a battle with cancer.

She was born Nov. 12, 1938, in Henry County, Ill., to Levi and Freida (Hostetler) Kropf.

She and her parents moved to Nashville, Ark., in 1975, where they lived until 1993, when she and her mother moved to Missouri.

Survivors include four brothers, Jacob, Sedalia, Loyal, Shelbina, Wilbert, Clarksville, Ark., and Sam, Green Forest, Ark.; eight sisters, Rhoda Eigsti, Halfway, Mary Miller and Martha Hostetler, both of Buffalo, Joy Kempf, Viola, Ark., Carol Kropf, Halfway, Sarah Miller and Eva Hostetler, both of Miller, and Eunice Garretson, Shelbina.

Services were Monday, Nov. 30, in the Pleasant View Amish-Mennonite Church, Buffalo. Burial was in the Pleasant View Amish-Mennonite Cemetery, under direction of Fraker Funeral Home, Marshfield.
